DOC.HEAD: Tutu in Holy Land; Supports Palestinian State
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa told a group of Moslem clerics and Palestinian activists Saturday that he supports the Palestinian struggle for an independent state. He made the comment during a five-day Christmas pilgrimage to the Holy Land that has angered some Israelis. The nation's two chief rabbis have refused to meet with Tutu, and some Israelis say the visit could provoke Christmas rioting among Palestinians. Near the Al Aqsa mosque, one of Islam's holiest sites, Tutu bowed his head in a moment of silent prayer at a stone platform in memory of more than 600 Palestinians killed by Christian militiamen in 1982 at refugee camps near Beirut, Lebanon. ``We support the struggle of the Palestinian people in their longing for statehood and independence,'' Tutu told assembled Moslem clerics and Palestinian activists. Among about 30 Palestinian dignitaries was Feisal Husseini, a leading activist in the occupied territories who supports the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``We pray that the day will come soon when a Palestinian state will exist side-by-side with a Jewish state and Arab and Jew will hold hands together,'' Tutu said. ``We come as those who know suffering from the inside, and we hope that our presence in this country will bring hope and encouragement to the people who are the victims of injustice and oppression.'' he said. ``We are struggling for our own self-determination in South Africa.'' Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his efforts to end racial discrimination in his homeland, spent the morning in meetings with Palestinian religious leaders. He then visited Judaism's holiest site, the Western Wall in Jerusalem, where one Orthodox Jew shouted ``Don't desecrate the wall!'' as Tutu approached. Tutu met with Rabbi Yehuda Getz, the rabbi in charge of the Western Wall, and prayed at the site while ultra-orthodox Jews sang and danced in the background in celebration of the second night of the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah. Earlier Saturday, Tutu, leader of South Africa's Anglican Church, met with the patriarchs of the Latin, Greek Orthodox and Armenian churches. The civil rights crusader arrived Friday for his visit. He was scheduled to visit Bethlehem in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Christmas Eve and preach in Jerusalem on Christmas Day.
